title: A two parter...
content: Characters in a book must have stakes. The reader must be convinced that there are important reasons for their actions, and that the consequences of failure can be dire. In police procedurals, detectives investigate and solve crimes. That‚Äôs their job, their stakes. If they don‚Äôt catch a murderer, for example, will someone else die? For soldiers, the reason they enlist to fight in a war, even at the cost of their own lives, may be because of duty and patriotism. Perhaps the stakes for a protagonist (or antagonist) are personal, like revenge for a past wrong. Think of the movie ‚ÄòTaken‚Äô with Liam Neeson, for example, or ‚ÄòThe Count of Monte Cristo‚Äô by Alexander Dumas. This leads me to ‚ÄòThe Alice Network‚Äô and the stakes found in the story. The book is about the intertwined lives of two people: Evelyn (Eve), a young British woman whose patriotism caused her to become a spy in the Great War (WWI), and Charlotte (Charlie), an American college age woman on a personally important trip to post-WWII Europe. The reader bounces back and forth in time with these women, separate and together, on their quests. Evelyn becomes a spy to help end the war quickly; Charlie runs away into France to find a cousin she hasn‚Äôt seen or heard from in years. Except I was unconvinced by their reasons for doing these things--their stakes--and it was frustrating. Both made huge human errors‚Äîthrough ego, grief, and self-pity‚Äîthat strayed into the clich√© and seemed to artificially drive the story. And I didn‚Äôt really like either of them. They came together during the post WWII time period‚Äîa shattered, bitter older Eve and the na√Øve Charlie‚Äîin coincidence, not my favorite fictional trope.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I do see what the other reviewers are saying, the part of the book that takes place during WWI does seem to be written better than the part that takes place in 1947. I didn't love Charlie at first either but she grew on me. I do feel it's worth reading. The joining of the time periods was a bit contrived but the ride is fun. I loved reading about this female spy network that actually existed and played an important part in gathering intelligence in WWI. She does a good job of describing the war torn towns and how badly the people were affected by the shortages and the fear and stress of life under German rule. She talks about many issues specific to women. I see what the others are saying about it being a "chick-lit" book disguised as a historical fiction book, but hey, I like a little romance. I felt that it was whitewashed enough that I didn't have nightmares but realistic enough that I got the point. I have had to put down many good books because I just can't take the horrors depicted, the torture scenes etc. In fact I've had to swear off fabulous authors because I can't sleep. So if you are like me, and you like a little chick lit thrown into your historical fiction, but yet still want to read about a substantially interesting time period and some awesome women that spied on the Germans, risking life and limb quite literally, then go for it. I couldn't put it down until the final sappy page!!! No shame in rooting for some happiness amongst the ruins.

title: Verified Purchase
content: The Alice Network is everything I'm looking for in historical fiction.  Historical facts and intriguing historical figures are seamlessly woven with a plausible fictional story and characters that enrich the history.  What makes it better?  Take something that deserves the spotlight, but has somehow not received the notice it deserved, and make it shine.  Women are so often lost to the pages of history, even when playing critical roles, like the Alice Network was.  Kate Quinn brings us one of the greatest spies against the Germans in World War I and the network of operatives she ran in occupied Northern France.  The price they paid, at the time and through the decades after, is deftly portrayed throughout.  Eve, Lili and Violette earn their monikers of fleurs du mal, as well as that of heroes.  The story moves forward to 1947, when Charlie, searching for her cousin who has disappeared in the fog of World War II France, appears on Eve's doorstep.  It is difficult to fully understand the impact that two major wars in less than 40 years, can have on the people and countries where so many of the battles were fought and lives were lost.  Finn, Eve's driver, is more than a side character; he helps illustrate some of those WWII scars.  There are no stones left unturned, including some direct quotes taken from history.  This is a spectacular book and I highly recommend it.  Fans of historical fiction will especially enjoy this one.

title: solid read!
content: I really enjoyed this novel. I was hesitant at first since it is one of those books that cover two different time periods at once. One story follows a woman in WWI who becomes part of a spy network...the Alice Network. The other story follows a young woman in 1949 who is looking for her cousin who was lost in France during WWII. I don‚Äôt often like books that jump back and forth in time from one chapter to the next. But the way the stories of all three women intertwine is so well done and the characters are so intriguing that I had trouble putting the book down. I learned so much about both wars that I never knew before. The descriptions of society and women‚Äôs place in the society of each time period was most interesting to me. Women can face different challenges than men in everyday let alone extreme situations and the challenges these three women faced in their lives are extraordinary to say the least. The book does a great job of explaining how society and war can affect women in particular. Now I am making it sound like some kind of ‚Äòchick-lit‚Äô novel and it is certainly not that. Are we so used to viewing war from a man‚Äôs point of view that a work about women in war is somehow less important? If anyone thinks that, they need to read this book to learn exactly what the Alice Network was, how it operated and how important it was to the success of the Allies in WWI.
